{{Use dmy dates|date=June 2011}} A '''film producer''' is a person who oversees the production of a film.<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url=http://www.producersguild.org/?page=faq|title=Frequently Asked Questions - Producers Guild of America|website=www.producersguild.org|access-date=2017-03-19}}</ref> Either employed by a [[production company]] or working [[Independent film|independently]], producers plan and coordinate various aspects of film production, such as selecting the script; coordinating writing, directing, and editing; and arranging financing.<ref name=":1">{{Cite web |url = http://lfs.org.uk/full-time-study/ma-filmmaking/areas-study/producing|title=Producing |publisher= London Film School|website= lfs.org.uk |language =en|access-date=}}</ref>
During the "discovery stage," the producer finds and selects promising material for development.<ref name=":1"/> Then, unless the film is based on an existing script, the producer has to hire a [[screenwriter]] and oversee the [[Filmmaking#Development|development of the script]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.onetonline.org/link/summary/27-2012.01|title=27-2012.01 - Producers|website=www.onetonline.org|language=en|access-date=2017-03-19}}</ref> Once a script is completed, the producer will lead a [[Pitch (filmmaking)|pitch]] to secure the financial backing (a "[[Green-light|green light]]") to allow production to begin.
The producer also supervises the pre-production, production, and post-production stages of filmmaking. One of the most important tasks is to hire the [[Film director|director]] and other key crew members. Whereas the director makes the creative decisions during the production, the producer typically manages the logistics and business operations, though some directors also produce their own films. The producer is tasked with making sure the film is delivered on time and within budget,<ref name=":14">{{Cite web|url=https://nationalcareersservice.direct.gov.uk/job-profiles/tv-or-film-producer#|title=TV or film producer|website=nationalcareersservice.direct.gov.uk|language=en|access-date=2017-02-18}}</ref> and has the final say on creative decisions. Finally, the producer will oversee the marketing and [[Film distribution|distribution]].
For various reasons, producers cannot always supervise all of the production. In this case, the main producer may hire and delegate work to [[executive producer]]s, [[line producer]]s, or [[unit production manager]]s.<ref name="nyt22">{{cite news|url=http://mediadecoder.blogs.nytimes.com/2012/11/08/three-studios-agree-to-plan-to-certify-who-deserves-to-be-a-producer/|title=Three Studios Agree to Let a Guild Certify Credits for Film Producers|last=Cieply|first=Michael|date=8 November 2012|newspaper=The New York Times|accessdate=19 November 2012}}</ref> {{TOC limit|2}}
==Types== Different types of producers and their roles within the industry today include (in no order of seniority):
===Executive producer=== {{Main|Executive producer}} The executive producer oversees all of the other producers working on the same project. They make sure that the producers are fulfilling their roles on the given production. They can also be in charge of managing the film's finances and handling all other business aspects of the film.<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":2">Zetti, Herbert (2011). ''Television Production Handbook 12th Edition''. Cengage Learning. p. 7. {{ISBN|978-1285052670}}</ref>
===Line producer=== {{Main|Line producer}} The line producer manages the staff and day-to-day operations and the oversees each and every physical aspect that is involved in the making of a film or television program. The line producer can be credited as "produced by" in certain cases.<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":2" />
===Supervising producer=== The supervising producer supervises the creative process of screenplay development and often aids in script re-writes. They can also fulfill the executive producer's role of overseeing other producers.<ref name=":0" />
===Producer=== Within the production process, a producer can oversee, arrange, manage, and begin every single aspect. He or she is involved in every single stage of the overall production process.<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":2" />
===Co-producer=== A co-producer is a member of a team of producers that perform all of the functions and roles that a single producer would have in a single given project.<ref name=":0" />
===Coordinating producer or production coordinator=== {{Main|Production coordinator}} A coordinating producer coordinates the work/role of multiple producers who are trying to achieve a shared result.<ref name=":0" />
===Associate producer or assistant producer=== The associate or assistant producer helps the producer during the production process. He/she can sometimes be involved in coordinating others' jobs, such as creating peoples' schedules and hiring the main talent.<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":2" />
===Segment producer=== A segment producer produces one or more single specific segments of a multi-segment film or television production.<ref name=":0" />
===Field Producer=== A field producer helps the producer by overseeing all of the production that takes place outside of the studio in specific locations for the film.<ref name=":2" />
==Responsibilities== ===Development (film rights)=== During this stage of the production process, producers bring together people like the [[film director]], [[cinematographer]], and [[production designer]].<ref name=":03">{{Cite web|url=http://creativeskillset.org/job_roles/757_producer|title=Producer|website=creativeskillset.org|language=en|access-date=2017-02-18}}</ref> Unless the film is supposed to be based on an original script, the producer has to find an appropriate [[screenwriter]].<ref name="rottentomatoes.com2">{{cite web|url=http://www.rottentomatoes.com/m/casino_royale/news/1648610/007_writers_to_tackle_quotbarbarellaquot/|title=writers Neal Purvis and Robert Wade have been hired to pen the screenplay for producer Dino de Laurentiis|accessdate=13 April 2007}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.filmmakers.com/artists/williamgoldman/biography/page2.htm|title=Goldman was contacted by director/producer Rob Reiner to write the screenplay|accessdate=14 March 2011}}</ref> If an existing script is considered flawed, they are able to order a new version or make the decision to hire a [[script doctor]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.davidlynch.de/dunetimeout.html|title=He began work on the script. And worked on it and worked on it, pushing it through seven drafts before arriving at a version with which de Laurentiis was satisfied|accessdate=11 November 2010|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20101121133818/http://davidlynch.de/dunetimeout.html|archive-date=21 November 2010|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.uni-duesseldorf.de/WWW/PhilFak/fshisto/jb/thespy.htm|title=Broccoli insisted on a rewrite, claiming to the story was too political for a 007 film. Writer Christopher Wood was brought on board to collaborate with Maibaum and expand upon Broccoli's personal concept for the film|accessdate=14 March 2013|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130510193135/http://www.uni-duesseldorf.de/WWW/PhilFak/fshisto/jb/thespy.htm|archivedate=10 May 2013|df=dmy-all}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/film/2010/aug/04/tom-mankiewicz-obituary|title=the producers Albert R Broccoli and Harry Saltzman hired him for two weeks to doctor the Richard Maibaum script of Diamonds Are Forever|last=Bergan|first=Ronald|date=4 August 2010|work=The Guardian|location=London|accessdate=4 August 2010}}</ref> The producer also has the final say on which [[film director]], cast members, or other staff get hired.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.tcm.com/this-month/article/79836%7C0/War-and-Peace.html|title=Next De Laurentiis hired King Vidor, director of Duel in the Sun (1946) and The Fountainhead (1949) to make the movie|accessdate=14 March 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/obituaries/culture-obituaries/film-obituaries/8127250/Dino-De-Laurentiis.html|title=Dino De Laurentiis [obituary]|quote =He also stuck loyally by gifted American directors when they were out of favour or off form. Robert Altman made one of his less successful pictures, Buffalo Bill and the Indians (1976), for De Laurentiis, who also helped the luckless Michael Cimino back on his feet after the commercial disaster of Heaven's Gate|date=11 November 2010|work=The Daily Telegraph|location=London|accessdate=}}</ref> In some cases, they also have the last word when it comes to casting questions.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.uni-duesseldorf.de/WWW/PhilFak/fshisto/jb/octopus.htm|title=Octopussy|quote =Cubby Broccoli personally broke his own golden rule and cast her as the mysterious Octopussy|accessdate=|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130510170037/http://www.uni-duesseldorf.de/WWW/PhilFak/fshisto/jb/octopus.htm|archivedate=10 May 2013|df=dmy-all}}</ref> A producer's role will also consist of approving locations, the studio hire, the final [[shooting script]], the [[production schedule]], and the budget. More time and money spent in pre-production can reduce the time and money wasted during production time.<ref name=":03"/>
===Pre-production=== During production, the producer's job is to make sure the film stays on schedule and under budget.<ref name=":14"/> They will always be in contact with directors and other key creative team members.<ref name=":03"/><ref name = bergan>{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/film/2011/jan/30/bernd-eichinger-obituary|title=Bernd Eichinger [obituary]|quote =In 1979, Eichinger bought a large stake in the Munich-based production and distribution company Constantin Film, which he ran as a hands-on producer for over 30 years|last=Bergan|first=Ronald|work=The Guardian|location=London|accessdate=}}</ref><ref name = europacorp>{{cite web|url=http://www.spiegel.de/international/business/the-movie-business-luc-besson-s-growing-empire-a-612371.html|title=Europacorp studio posted $186 million in revenues last year, making it second only to Germany's Constantin Film as Europe's largest independent studio|accessdate=10 March 2009}}</ref> In addition to this, cast and [[film crew]] often work at different times or places, and certain films even require a [[second unit]]. The executive producer of the ''[[Star Wars]]'' original trilogy was [[George Lucas]] himself, the creator of the ''Star Wars'' universe.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.lucasfilm.com/inside/bio/georgelucas.html|title=Lucas continued the Star Wars saga as story writer and executive producer with The Empire Strikes Back in 1980 and Return of the Jedi in 1983.|accessdate=20 March 2013|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20040405085412/http://www.lucasfilm.com/inside/bio/georgelucas.html|archivedate=5 April 2004|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
===Production=== For various reasons, producers cannot always personally supervise all parts of their production. For example, some producers run a company which also deals with film distribution.<ref name = bergan/><ref name = europacorp/> Also, cast and [[film crew]] often work at different times and places, and certain films even require a [[second unit]].
===Post-production=== During post-production, the producer has the last word on whether sounds, music, or scenes have to be changed or cut. Even if the shooting has been finished, the producers can still demand that additional scenes be filmed. In the case of a negative [[test screening]], producers may even demand and get an alternative film ending. This happened, for example, with ''[[First Blood]].'' The test audience reacted very negatively when Rambo died, so the producers re-shot a new ending.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://davidmorrell.net/rambo-pages/david-morrell-on-rambo/|title=test audiences nearly rioted after cheering for Rambo and then seeing him die. So the producers went back to Hope, British Columbia, the location for the film, and shot a new ending in which Rambo lives|accessdate=15 March 2013}}</ref> In addition to this, producers work with marketing and distribution companies in order to sell the film or arrange its distribution rights.<ref name=":14"/>
==The union== Within the industry, all of the producers union contracts are negotiated by [[Alliance of Motion Picture and Television Producers|The Alliance of Motion Picture and Television Producers (AMPTP)]]. It was founded in 1924 by the U.S Trade Association as the Association of Motion Picture Producers.<ref name=":4">{{cite web|url = http://collections.oscars.org/link/bio/1473|title = Association of Motion Picture and Television Producers (AMPTP) records|website =Special Collections: Margaret Herrick Library |publisher = Academy of Motion Picture Arts & Sciences}}</ref> It was originally created to only negotiate labor contracts, but during the mid-1930s they took over all contract negotiation responsibilities that were once controlled by the [[Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences]].<ref name=":4" /> This alliance negotiates with a wide range of other associations when dealing with producers union contracts. These associations include, the [[American Federation of Television and Radio Artists]] (AFTRA), the [[Directors Guild of America]] (DGA), and the [[Screen Actors Guild]] (SAG).<ref name=":3">{{Cite web|url=http://amptp.org/|title=AMPTP|website=amptp.org|access-date=2017-03-19}}</ref> They negotiate over eighty industry wide union agreements and on behalf of 350 producers within the industry. It has been responsible for negotiating all of these union contracts within the industry since 1982. Today, it is considered the industry's official contract negotiation representative for everyone within the industry.<ref>[http://filmmakeriq.com/2012/09/a-guide-to-hollywood-unions/ "A Guide to Hollywood Unions | FilmmakerIQ.com"]. ''filmmakeriq.com''. Retrieved 2017-02-19.</ref>
==Career process== There are many different ways to become a film producer. [[Stanley Kramer]] started as an [[Film editing|editor]] and [[writer]], while other producers started as actors or directors.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cinema.ucla.edu/collections/stanley-kramer-collection|title=Mr. Kramer began his career in the 1930s as an editor and writer, later forming an independent production company|accessdate=15 March 2013}}</ref>
However, most producers start in a college, university or film school. On the occasion of announcing his own film school, 'École de la Cité, film producer [[Luc Besson]] admitted that at the beginning of his career, he would have appreciated the chance to attend a film school.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ecoledelacite.com/en/|title=École de la cité|website=Ecole de la cité}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=https://variety.com/2012/film/news/luc-besson-launches-film-school-1118055818/|title=Luc Besson launches film school|work=Variety|accessdate=15 March 2013}}</ref> [[Film school]]s and many [[University|universities]] offer [[Academic degree|degree courses]] that include film production knowledge, with some courses that are especially designed for future film producers.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.screenacademyscotland.ac.uk/content-114|title=The MFA Advanced Film Practice programme aims to equip you with the creative, professional and technical knowledge you will need to enter the professional arena as a writer, producer or director.|accessdate=15 March 2013|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130416155055/http://www.screenacademyscotland.ac.uk/content-114|archivedate=16 April 2013|df=dmy-all}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.fondazionecsc.it/context.jsp?ID_LINK=18&area=7|title=The training course last three years and the interdisciplinary teaching programme prepares students in the specific areas of directing, scriptwriting, acting, photography, editing, sound techniques, production, set design, props and wardrobe|accessdate=15 March 2013}}</ref> These courses focus on key topics like [[Pitch (filmmaking)|pitching]], [[script development]], script assessment, shooting schedule design, and budgeting.<ref name="Filmakademie2">{{cite web|url=https://www.filmakademie.de/en/studium/course-of-study/production/production/|title=Course of Study - Production |accessdate= |website = Filmakademie Baden Wurttemberg GmbH|language = en}}</ref><ref name=":1"/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.westminster.ac.uk/about-us/schools/media/departments/photography|title=Our BA in Film Production is one of our most highly sought-after courses.|accessdate=15 March 2013|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130202000449/http://www.westminster.ac.uk/about-us/schools/media/departments/photography|archivedate=2 February 2013|df=dmy-all}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dffb.de/html/en/studium/produktion|title=Producing seminars teach through practical studies in production, script development, budgeting, and media economics|accessdate=15 March 2013}}</ref> Students can also expect practical training regarding post-production.<ref>{{cite web|url= http://www.bfm.ee/programmes/film-arts/film-arts-ma/|title=All student films are developed, shot and post-produced in teams, closely mirroring a realistic industry work process in order to ease graduates' transitions to the professional environment|accessdate=15 March 2013}}</ref> Training at a top producing school is one of the most efficient ways a student can show professionals they are not a rookie.<ref name=":22">{{Cite news|url=https://www.nyfa.edu/student-resources/becoming-a-producer-tried-and-tested-career-paths/|title=Becoming a Producer - Tried and Tested Career Paths|date=2015-06-12|access-date=2017-02-20|language=en-US|newspaper=Student Resources}}</ref>
While education is one way to begin a career as a film producer, experience is also required to land a job. [[Internship]]s are a great way to gain experience while in school and give students a solid foundation on which to build their career. Many internships are paid, which enable students to earn money while gaining hands-on skills from industry professionals.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.thebalance.com/how-to-get-a-production-internship-1283507|title=Where to Look for Internship Programs in Entertainment|access-date=2017-02-03|newspaper=The Balance}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://creativeskillset.org/creative_industries/film/ways_into_the_industry|title=Ways into the film industry - Film Industry - Creative Skillset|website=creativeskillset.org|language=en|access-date=2017-02-03}}</ref> Through internships, students get to network with people in the film industry as well. This pays off in the end when looking for jobs after school. Once an internship is over, the next step typically will be to land a junior position, such as a [[production assistant]].<ref name=":22" />
Although rates can vary based on a producer's role and the location of filming, the average salary can start anywhere from $20,000 to $70,000, even doubling when working in Los Angeles.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.nyfa.edu/student-resources/jobs-film-average-salary-career-paths/|title=Jobs in Film: Average Salary & Career Paths|date=2014-12-01|access-date=2017-02-20|language=en-US|newspaper=Student Resources}}</ref> The average annual salary for a producer in the U.S. is $109,844. When examining more than 15,000 producers in the Los Angeles metropolitan area, the average annual salary is $138,640.<ref name="entertainment.howstuffworks.com2">{{cite web|url=http://entertainment.howstuffworks.com/highest-paying-jobs-film-industry.htm#page=1|title=10 Highest Paying Jobs in the Film Industry|date=30 May 2008|publisher=}}</ref> Producers can also have an agreement to take a percentage of a movie's sales.<ref name="entertainment.howstuffworks.com2" />
There is no average work day for a film producer, since their tasks are changing from day to day. A producer's work hours are often irregular and can consist of very long days with the possibility of working nights and weekends.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.prospects.ac.uk/job-profiles/television-film-video-producer|title=Television/film/video producer job profile {{!}} Prospects.ac.uk|website=www.prospects.ac.uk|language=en|access-date=2017-02-20}}</ref>
==Notable producers== {{Main|List of film producers}}
==References== {{Reflist|30em}}

[[File:Flaubert-Giraud.jpg|thumb|Flaubert at about the age of 50. Portrait by [[Eugène Giraud]]]] The '''letters of Gustave Flaubert''', the 19th-century French novelist, range in date from 1829, when he was 7 or 8 years old, to a day or two before his death in 1880.{{cite web |url=http://flaubert.univ-rouen.fr/jet/public/correspondance/feuilletage_liste_elts.php?t=C |title=Présentation des lettres par ordre chronologique |editor1-last=Leclerc |editor1-first=Yvan |editor2-last=Girard |editor2-first=Danielle |date=2 November 2017 |website=Correspondence: Édition électronique |publisher=Centre Flaubert, Université de Rouen |language=French |access-date=2 August 2018 }} They are considered one of the finest bodies of letters in French literature, admired even by many who are critical of [[Gustave Flaubert|Flaubert]]'s novels.{{sfn|Barnes|2003}} His main correspondents include family members, business associates and fellow-writers such as [[Théophile Gautier]], the [[Goncourt brothers]], [[Guy de Maupassant]], [[Charles Augustin Sainte-Beuve]], [[George Sand]], [[Ivan Turgenev]] and [[Émile Zola]]. They provide a valuable glimpse of his methods of work and his literary philosophy, as well as documenting his social life, political opinions, and increasing disgust with bourgeois society. == Correspondents == 4481 letters by Flaubert survive,{{sfn|Leclerc|Girard|2017}} a number which would have been considerably higher but for a series of burnings of his letters to his friends. Many of those addressed to [[Maxime Du Camp]], [[Guy de Maupassant]] and [[Louis Bouilhet]] were destroyed in this way.{{cite book |last1=Porter |first1=Laurence M. |last2=Gray |first2=Eugene F. |year=2002 |title=Gustave Flaubert's ''Madame Bovary'': A Reference Guide |url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=T_BcAAAAMAAJ&q=%22most+of+his+letters+to+and+from+his+close+friends%22&dq=%22most+of+his+letters+to+and+from+his+close+friends%22&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwiot9SCn87cAhXLyaQKHUWuCR8Q6AEIJzAA |location=Westport, Conn. |publisher=Greenwood Press |page=145 |isbn=0313319162 |access-date=2 August 2018 }} From those that survive it appears that his principal correspondents were as follows.{{cite web |url=http://flaubert.univ-rouen.fr/jet/public/correspondance/feuilletage_liste_elts.php?corpus=correspondance |title=Présentation des lettres par destinataire |editor1-last=Leclerc |editor1-first=Yvan |editor2-last=Girard |editor2-first=Danielle |date=2 November 2017 |website=Correspondence: Édition électronique |publisher=Centre Flaubert, Université de Rouen |language=French |access-date=2 August 2018 }} His family members:
{{columns-list|colwidth=25em| * Anne Justine Caroline Flaubert, his mother * Caroline Hamard, his sister * Caroline Commanvile, his niece * Ernest Commanville, his niece's husband }} His friends, associates and readers:
{{columns-list|colwidth=25em| * [[Agénor Bardoux]], politician * Princesse [[Mathilde Bonaparte]], niece of [[Napoleon|Napoleon I]], cousin of [[Napoleon III]], literary patron * [[Amélie Bosquet]] ([[:fr:Amélie Bosquet|FR]]), feminist writer * Louis Bouilhet, poet and friend of Flaubert from childhood * Marie-Louise Léonie Brainne (née Rivière), journalist * Maxime Du Camp, journalist, photographer and travelling companion of Flaubert * [[Marie-Sophie Leroyer de Chantepie]] ([[:fr:Marie-Sophie Leroyer de Chantepie|FR]]), minor novelist * [[Georges Charpentier]], publisher * [[Ernest Chevalier]] ([[:fr:Ernest Chevalier|FR]]), judge and friend from childhood * [[Louise Colet]], poet and Flaubert's lover * Jules Duplan, businessman * [[Ernest-Aimé Feydeau]], writer * Frédéric Fovard, notary * [[Théophile Gautier]], poet and writer * Edma Roger des Genettes, literary and artistic ''salonnière'' * [[Edmond de Goncourt|Edmond]] and [[Jules de Goncourt]], novelists and diarists * Edmond Laporte, local politician and businessman * [[Alphonse Lemerre]], publisher * Philippe Leparfait, adopted son of Louis Bouilhet * [[Michel Lévy]], publisher * Guy de Maupassant, short-story writer * [[Claudius Popelin]] ([[:fr:Claudius Popelin|FR]]), painter, writer and sometime lover of Princesse Mathilde Bonaparte * [[Edgar Raoul-Duval]], politician * [[Charles Augustin Sainte-Beuve]], critic and novelist * [[George Sand]], novelist * [[Hippolyte Taine]], writer on art and literature * [[Gertrude Tennant]], English society hostess * [[Marie-Anne Detourbay|Jeanne de Tourbey]], successful ''[[Demimonde|demi-mondaine]]'' * Jules Troubat, Sainte-Beuve's secretary * [[Ivan Turgenev]], Russian novelist * [[Émile Zola]], novelist{{sfn|Steegmuller|1954|pp=56–57}}{{cite news |last=Flood |first=Alison |date=27 July 2009 |title=Letters Reveal Flaubert's English 'Amitié Amoureuse' |url=https://www.theguardian.com/books/2009/jul/27/flaubert-amitie-amoureuse-letters |work=The Guardian |location=London |access-date=2 August 2018 }}{{cite book |year=1980 |editor1-last=Steegmuller |editor1-first=Francis |title=The Letters of Gustave Flaubert 1830–1857 |url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=srZfwgWpQysC&pg=PA222&dq=%22contract+with+the+publisher+Michel%22&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwiemcfFqs7cAhVrCsAKHQTdAJAQ6AEIOTAD#v=onepage&q=%22contract%20with%20the%20publisher%20Michel%22&f=false |location=Cambridge, Mass. |publisher=Belknap Press of the Harvard University Press |page=222 |isbn=0674526368 |access-date=2 August 2018 }}{{sfn|Steegmuller|1982|pp=5, 18, 65 108, 133, 195, 219, 250, 251}}{{sfn|Winock|2016|pp=230, 312}}{{cite book |year=1969 |editor1-last=Thorlby |editor1-first=Anthony |title=The Penguin Companion to Literature. 2: European |url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=sIWnIOCXU7AC&q=%22French+critic+and+novelist+early%22&dq=%22French+critic+and+novelist+early%22&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjNtNDirc7cAhXKa8AKHa6NBxMQ6AEIKzAB |location=Harmondsworth |publisher=Penguin |pages=304, 686 |isbn=9780140510355 |access-date=2 August 2018 }} }} == Themes == Flaubert's personality was rigorously excluded from his novels, but in the letters, written at night after the day's literary work was done, he expresses much more spontaneously his own personal views.{{sfn|Steegmuller|1954|p=11}} Their themes often arise from his life as a reader and writer. They discuss the subject-matter and structural difficulties of his novels, and explore the problems Flaubert faced in their composition, giving the reader a unique glimpse of his art in the making.{{sfn|Lloyd|2004|p=76}} They illustrate his extensive reading of the creative literatures of France, England (he loved [[William Shakespeare|Shakespeare]], [[Lord Byron|Byron]] and [[Charles Dickens|Dickens]]), Germany and the classical world; also his deep researches into history, philosophy and the sciences.{{sfn|Le Calvez|2001|p=74}}{{sfn|Barnes|2002|p=244}} Above all, they constantly state and restate Flaubert's belief in the duty of the writer to maintain his independence, and in his own need to reach literary beauty through a quasi-scientific objectivity.{{sfn|Steegmuller|1954|pp=17–18}}{{sfn|Le Calvez|2001|p=75}}{{cite news |last=Hampshire |first=Stuart |author-link=Stuart Hampshire |date=16 December 1982 |title=In Flaubert's Laboratory |url=https://www.nybooks.com/articles/1982/12/16/in-flauberts-laboratory/ |work=The New York Review of Books |access-date=2 August 2018 }} But his letters also demonstrate an enjoyment of the simple pleasures of Flaubert's youth. Friendship, love, conversation, a delight in foreign travel, the pleasures of the table and of the bed are all in evidence.{{sfn|Lloyd|2004|p=67}}{{cite book |last1=Vidal |first1=Gore |author-link1=Gore Vidal |year=1982 |title=Pink Triangle and Yellow Star, and Other Essays (1976–1982) |url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=xDQgAQAAIAAJ&q=%22brothels+and+baths+of%22&dq=%22brothels+and+baths+of%22&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjul5S1l8_cAhXIK8AKHR8tD68Q6AEIQzAF |location=London |publisher=Heinemann |page=29 |isbn=9780434830756 |access-date=2 August 2018 }} These do not disappear in his maturer years, but they are offset by discussions of politics and current affairs which reveal an increasing disgust with society, especially bourgeois society, and with the age he lived in.{{cite book |last1=Lloyd |first1=Rosemary |year=2014 |orig-year=1990 |title=Madame Bovary |url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=0F4tBAAAQBAJ&pg=PA21&dq=%22flaubert's+letters%22&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwi3jIb9hK3aAhVlKsAKHdNpAMY4FBDoAQg-MAU#v=onepage&q=%22flaubert's%20letters%22&f=false |location=Abingdon |publisher=Routledge |page=21 |isbn=9781138799349 |access-date=2 August 2018 }}{{sfn|Le Calvez|2001|p=74}} They exude a sadness and a sense of having grown old before his time.{{sfn|Lloyd|2004|p=80}} As a whole, said the literary critic Eric Le Calvez, Flaubert's correspondence, "reveals his vision of life and of the relation between life and art: since the human condition is miserable, life can be legitimated only through an eternal pursuit of art."{{sfn|Le Calvez|2001|p=74}} == Critical reception == [[File:Flaubert letter.jpg|thumb|An 1877 letter from [[Gustave Flaubert]] to [[Léon Cladel]]]] For many years after the first publication of the letters critical opinion was divided. [[Albert Thibaudet]] thought them "the expression of a first-rate intellect", and [[André Gide]] wrote that "For more than five years his correspondence took the place of the Bible at my bedside. It was my reservoir of energy". [[Frank Harris]] said that in his letters "he lets himself go and unconsciously paints himself for us to the life; and this Gustave Flaubert is enormously more interesting than anything in ''Madame Bovary''".{{cite book |last1=Harris |first1=Frank |author-link1=Frank Harris |year=1927 |title=Latest Contemporary Portraits |location=New York |publisher=Macaulay |page=206 }} On the other hand [[Marcel Proust]] found Flaubert's epistolary style "even worse" than that of his novels, while for [[Henry James]] the Flaubert of the letters was "impossible as a companion".{{sfn|Steegmuller|1982|pp=xvii–xviii}} This ambivalence is a thing of the past, and there is now widespread agreement that the Flaubert correspondence is one of the finest in French literature.{{sfn|Le Calvez|2001|p=74}} Publication of them "has crowned his reputation as the exemplary artist".{{cite web |url=http://www.oxfordreference.com/view/10.1093/acref/9780192806871.001.0001/acref-9780192806871-e-2807?rskey=3k4M21&result=4 |title=The Oxford Companion to English Literature (7 ed.) |date=2009 |editor-last=Birch |editor-first=Dinah |editor-link=Dinah Birch |website=Oxford Reference |publisher=Oxford University Press |access-date=2 August 2018 }} [[Enid Starkie]] wrote that Flaubert was one of his own greatest literary creations, and that the letters might well be seen in the future as his greatest book, and the one in which "he has most fully distilled his personality and his wisdom".{{cite book |last1=Starkie |first1=Enid |year=1971 |title=Flaubert the Master: A Critical and Biographical Study (1856-1880) |location=London |publisher=Weidenfeld and Nicolson |pages=355-356 |isbn=0297002260 }} [[Jean-Paul Sartre]], an inveterate enemy of Flaubert's novels, considered the letters a perfect example of pre-Freudian [[Free association (psychology)|free association]], and for [[Julian Barnes]] this description "hints at their fluency, profligacy, range and sexual frankness; to which we should add power, control, wit, emotion and furious intelligence. The ''Correspondance''...has always added up to Flaubert's best biography."{{sfn|Barnes|2002|p=239}}{{sfn|Barnes|2003}} Rosemary Lloyd analyses the elements of their appeal as being "partly [their] wide sweep, partly the sense of seeing what Baudelaire called the strings and pulleys of the writer's workshop, and partly the immediacy of Flaubert's changeable, complex and challenging personality." She continues, "Reading Flaubert's correspondence brings startlingly alive a man of enormous complexity, of remarkable appetites and debilitating lethargies, a knotted network of prejudices, insights, blind spots, passions and ambitions."{{sfn|Lloyd|2004|pp=67, 83}} == Editions == * {{cite book |last1=Flaubert |first1=Gustave |year=1887–1893 |title=Correspondance |location=Paris |publisher=G. Charpentier }} This four-volume edition was the first to try to collect Flaubert's letters. The unnamed editor was Flaubert's niece Caroline Commanville; she censored the letters freely, cutting out many passages which she thought indecent or which referred unflatteringly to living persons, especially to herself, and very often failing to notify the reader of these cuts by the use of [[Ellipsis|ellipses]]. She also corrected his punctuation and sometimes "improved" his phrasing.{{sfn|Lloyd|2004|p=68}}{{sfn|Steegmuller|1982|pp=xv–xvi}}{{sfn|Barnes|2003}}{{sfn|Cléroux|2013}} * {{cite book |last1=Flaubert |first1=Gustave |year=1910 |title=Correspondance |location=Paris |publisher=Conard }} A five-volume edition which has been described as "seriously flawed".{{sfn|Winock|2016|p=422}}{{sfn|Cléroux|2013}} * {{cite book |year=1922–1925 |editor1-last=Descharmes |editor1-first=René |title=Correspondance |location=Paris |publisher=Librairie de France }} In four volumes. The first scholarly edition.{{sfn|Winock|2016|p=422}}{{sfn|Cléroux|2013}} * {{cite book |last1=Flaubert |first1=Gustave |title=Correspondance |location=Paris |publisher=Louis Conard }} In nine volumes, containing 1992 letters. Most of the notes were taken from René Descharmes' edition.{{sfn|Le Calvez|2001|p=75}}{{sfn|Cléroux|2013}} * {{cite book |year=1954 |editor1-last=Dumesnil |editor1-first=René |editor1-link=René Dumesnil |editor2-last=Pommier |editor2-first=Jean |editor3-last=Digeon |editor3-first=Claude |title=Correspondance: Supplément |location=Paris |publisher=Louis Conard, Jacques Lambert }} Adds 1296 letters to the edition of 1926–1933.{{sfn|Le Calvez|2001|p=75}}{{sfn|Cléroux|2013}} * {{cite book |year=1973–2007 |editor1-last=Bruneau |editor1-first=Jean |title=Correspondance |series=Bibliothèque de la Pléiade |location=Paris |publisher=Gallimard }} In five volumes, the first four edited by Jean Bruneau, and the fifth, which was published after Bruneau's death, co-edited with [[Yvan Leclerc]] ([[:fr:Yvan Leclerc|FR]]). This edition boasts an extremely thorough critical apparatus, with letters written to Flaubert, excerpts from the [[Goncourt Journal]] and other third-party documentation, together with explanatory and critical notes by the editor. Julian Barnes points out that in the third volume the appendices, notes and variants take up more pages than the letters themselves.{{cite news |last=Barnes |first=Julian |date=14 March 2008 |title=The Lost Governess |url=https://www.the-tls.co.uk/articles/public/julian-barnes-gustave-flaubert/ |work=TLS |location=London |access-date=3 August 2018 }}{{sfn|Barnes|2003}}{{sfn|Cléroux|2013}} * {{cite book |year=1974–1976 |editor1-last=Bardèche |editor1-first=Maurice |editor1-link=Maurice Bardèche |title=Correspondance |location=Paris |publisher=Club de l'Honnête Homme }} In five volumes.{{sfn|Cléroux|2013}} * {{cite book |year=2001 |editor1-last=Bonaccorso |editor1-first=Giovanni |title=Correspondance. Première édition scientifique |location=Saint-Genouph |publisher=Nizet }} Two volumes were published, taking the edition up to 1861, but the editor's death brought the project to a halt.{{sfn|Cléroux|2013}} * {{cite web |url=http://flaubert.univ-rouen.fr/correspondance/edition/ |title=Correspondance: Édition électronique |editor1-last=Leclerc |editor1-first=Yvan |editor2-last=Girard |editor2-first=Danielle |date=2 November 2017 |website=Correspondence de Flaubert |publisher=Centre Flaubert, Université de Rouen |access-date=29 July 2018 }} A freely available Web-based edition comprising 4481 letters, 134 of which have not previously been published.{{sfn|Leclerc|Girard|2017}}{{cite web |url=http://flaubert.univ-rouen.fr/jet/public/correspondance/feuilletage.php?t=I |title=Correspondance de Flaubert - Lettres Inédites |editor1-last=Leclerc |editor1-first=Yvan |editor2-last=Girard |editor2-first=Danielle |date=2 November 2017 |website=Correspondence: Édition électronique |publisher=Centre Flaubert, Université de Rouen |access-date=3 August 2018 }} There have also been many single-correspondent editions of Flaubert's letters to one or another of his friends and associates, and selections from the collected letters.{{sfn|Cléroux|2013}} == Translations == * {{cite book |last1=Tarver |first1=John Charles |year=1895 |title=Gustave Flaubert: As Seen in his Works and Correspondence |location=Westminster |publisher=A. Constable }} The first selection of the letters in English.{{sfn|Winock|2016|p=517}}{{cite web |url=https://scholarworks.uno.edu/cgi/viewcontent.cgi?article=1086&context=engl_facpubs |title=The Hermit of Croisset: Flaubert's Fiercely Enduring Perfectionism |last=Goodman |first=Richard |date=2009 |website=English Faculty Publications |publisher=University of New Orleans |page=4 |format=PDF |access-date=3 August 2018 }} * {{cite book |translator-last1=Mckenzie |translator-first1=Aimée L. |year=1922 |title=The George Sand – Gustave Flaubert Letters |location=London |publisher=Duckworth }}{{cite book |last1=Massardier-Kenney |first1=Françoise |author-link1=Françoise Massardier-Kenney |year=2000 |title=Gender in the Fiction of George Sand |url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=p2BQq6dskAoC&pg=PA188&dq=%22flaubert+letters+london+duckworth%22&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjlnKOaydHcAhURLFAKHcFND6oQ6AEILTAB#v=onepage&q=%22flaubert%20letters%20london%20duckworth%22&f=false |location=Amsterdam |publisher=Rodopi |page=188 |isbn=9042007079 |access-date=3 August 2018 }} * {{cite book |translator-last1=Cohen |translator-first1=J. M. |translator-link1=J. M. Cohen |year=1950 |editor1-last=Rumbold |editor1-first=Richard |title=Gustave Flaubert: Letters |location=London |publisher=Weidenfeld and Nicolson }} Includes 122 letters.{{cite journal |last1=Cranston |first1=Maurice |author-link1=Maurice Cranston |date=12 May 1950 |title=Flaubert's Letters |url=http://archive.spectator.co.uk/article/12th-may-1950/26/flauberts-letters |journal=The Spectator |page=26 |access-date=29 July 2018 }} * {{cite book |year=1954 |editor1-last=Steegmuller |editor1-first=Francis |editor1-link=Francis Steegmuller |title=The Selected Letters of Gustave Flaubert |location=London |publisher=Hamish Hamilton }} According to ''[[The Nation]]'', Steegmuller "edited them with discretion after translating them with authority".{{cite book |year=1977 |editor1-last=Sypher |editor1-first=F. J. |title=The Reader's Adviser: A Layman's Guide to Literature. Volume 2 |url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=NXg0AAAAMAAJ&q=%22epistolary+literature+and+Francis%22&dq=%22epistolary+literature+and+Francis%22&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjXk-Cs7NHcAhXKKcAKHXQyB1IQ6AEIJzAA |edition=12th |location=New York |publisher=Bowker |page=213 |isbn=0835208524 |access-date=3 August 2018 }}{{sfn|Cléroux|2013}} * {{cite book |year=1972 |editor1-last=Steegmuller |editor1-first=Francis |title=Flaubert in Egypt: A Sensibility on Tour. A Narrative Drawn from Gustave Flaubert's Travel Notes and Letters |location=Boston |publisher=Little, Brown }}{{sfn|Porter|2001|p=354}} * {{cite book |year=1979–1982 |editor1-last=Steegmuller |editor1-first=Francis |title=The Letters of Gustave Flaubert |location=Cambridge, Mass. |publisher=Belknap Press of Harvard University Press }} In two volumes. Jean Bruneau, editor of the then half-completed Pléiade edition, gave Steegmuller unfettered access to all his files, including the manuscripts of newly-discovered letters, with the result that some appeared in Steegmuller's English before they had been published in the original French. Its publication, ''[[The Times]]'' later said, "was a major event in the English-speaking literary world".{{cite news |author= |title=Francis Steegmuller |work=The Times |location=London |date=27 October 1994 |page=21 }}{{sfn|Barnes|2003}}{{cite book |last1=Patton |first1=Susannah |year=2010 |title=A Journey into Flaubert's Normandy |url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=f36b0lAi0aMC&pg=PA248&dq=%22Press+1979+The+Letters+of+Gustave%22&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjlzvzsgtTcAhUFAsAKHYHeADoQ6AEILTAB#v=onepage&q=%22Press%201979%20The%20Letters%20of%20Gustave%22&f=false |location=Surry Hills, NSW |publisher=Accessible Publishing Systems |page=248 |isbn=9781458785435 |access-date=4 August 2018 }} * {{cite book |year=1985 |editor1-last=Beaumont |editor1-first=Barbara |title=Flaubert and Turgenev, a Friendship in Letters. The Complete Correspondence |location=London |publisher=Athlone }}{{sfn|Le Calvez|2001|p=76}} * {{cite book |translator-last1=Steegmuller |translator-first1=Francis |translator-last2=Bray |translator-first2=Barbara |translator-link2=Barbara Bray |year=1993 |title=Flaubert-Sand: The Correspondence |location=New York |publisher=Alfred A. Knopf }} Includes about 100 letters not to be found in the 1922 Mckenzie translation. Barbara Bray translated George Sand's letters, and Francis Steegmuller Flaubert's. It has been called "a graceful and expressive translation in a scrupulous edition that has the effect of the best kind of biography – and a double one at that."{{cite news |last=Fields |first=Beverly |date=7 March 1993 |title=Flaubert and Sand: Linked by Excellence |url=http://articles.chicagotribune.com/1993-03-07/entertainment/9303188035_1_flaubert-and-sand-flaubert-sand-suffrage |work=Chicago Tribune |access-date=4 August 2018 }}{{cite news |last=Shattuck |first=Roger |author-link=Roger Shattuck |date=21 February 1993 |title=Pen Pals par Excellence
